title: Lesson 04: Matrix Multiplication as Composition
objectives: Understand matrix multiplication as composition of transformations

cards.front: What does matrix multiplication represent geometrically?
cards.back:
Composition of linear transformations.

Multiplying matrices M₂M₁ means: first apply M₁, then apply M₂. The result is a single matrix representing both transformations combined.

cards.front: In which order do you read matrix multiplication M₂M₁?
cards.back:
Right to left.

M₂M₁ means: first apply M₁ (right), then apply M₂ (left).

This follows function notation: f(g(x)) applies g first.

cards.front:
How do you compute the product of two 2×2 matrices?

[a b][e f]
[c d][g h]
cards.back:
Track where basis vectors land after both transformations:

[ae+bg  af+bh]
[ce+dg  cf+dh]

Each column shows where the corresponding basis vector ends up.

cards.front:
Is matrix multiplication commutative?

Does AB = BA?
cards.back:
No! Matrix multiplication is NOT commutative.

AB ≠ BA in general.

Geometrically: rotating then shearing gives a different result than shearing then rotating.

cards.front:
Is matrix multiplication associative?

Does (AB)C = A(BC)?
cards.back:
Yes! Matrix multiplication IS associative.

(AB)C = A(BC)

Geometrically obvious: applying three transformations in sequence gives the same result regardless of how you group them.
